title: 204.14B — One-way lighting (3-plate ceiling rose): build flow + prove it (rig-safe)
description: Build a one-way lighting circuit using the 3-plate ceiling rose method and verify it is safe and ready for results recording on a training rig using a repeatable dead-testing routine.
learningOutcomes: Identify the three terminal groups in a 3-plate ceiling rose and what each one does.
Explain the rig-safe build flow from plan to recording results.
Carry out dead-testing procedures to confirm the circuit is safe and ready for results recording on a training rig.
Apply Prove → Test → Re-prove so readings are trustworthy (instrument + leads confirmed).

outcomes.text: Identify the three terminal groups in a ceiling rose and their functions.
Explain the sequence of the rig-safe build flow (Plan → Mount → Route → Terminate → Inspect → Test → Record).
Carry out dead tests and record results using a repeatable routine.
Use Prove → Test → Re-prove to avoid false results caused by leads/settings/instrument issues.

terms.definition: A ceiling rose with three terminal blocks: Loop (permanent live group), Neutral group, and Switched Live group to the lamp.
The terminal group where the supply Line and the switch feed (to COM) are connected together.
The conductor returning from the switch (from L1) that becomes live only when the switch is ON.
Circuit Protective Conductor; maintains the earth path through the circuit for safety.
Testing carried out on a circuit in a confirmed dead state (training-rig approved dead condition).
A routine to confirm your tester and leads are working before and after each test so results can be trusted.

content.title: The Systematic Build Flow (and how you prove it safely)
content.content:
A one-way lighting circuit (3-plate ceiling rose) is only as good as its build quality and the reliability of its test routine. This lesson is about doing it the same way every time.

## Step 0 — Rig-safe start
Confirm the training rig is in its approved dead state and your work area is clear. Identify the correct circuit before touching any conductors.

## Step 1 — Plan from the diagram (wire journey check)
Before you cut/strip anything, you must be able to explain:
- Which terminal group is the **Loop (permanent live)**.
- Which core is the **switch feed** (Loop → switch COM).
- Which core is the **switch return** (switch L1 → Rose switched live).
- Where the **Neutral group** joins supply neutral + lamp neutral.
- Where the **CPC** is terminated at every point.

## Step 2 — Mount accessories
Fix the CU/isolator (rig), switch box, and ceiling rose/batten holder. Covers must fit without crushing conductors.

## Step 3 — Route and prepare cables
- Bring the **sheath into every accessory** (no single-insulated cores exposed outside).
- Sleeve/identify immediately:
  - **Green/Yellow** on CPC at terminations.
  - **Brown** on any core used as a live (especially the switch return if it is blue).

## Step 4 — Terminate (follow the 3-plate map)
- **Loop group:** CU Line + switch feed to COM.
- **Neutral group:** CU Neutral + lamp neutral.
- **Switched Live group:** switch return from L1 + lamp live.
- **CPC:** continuous and terminated at each point (including the switch box).

## Step 5 — Dead inspection (decision gate)
You only proceed if inspection is a **Pass**. Stop-and-fix examples: exposed copper, damaged insulation, CPC missing/unterminated, loose terminations.

## Step 6 — Dead tests + recording (rig-safe)
You now prove the build using a repeatable routine and record results.

### Dead Test Routine (must be used)
For each test:
1) **Prove** the tester/function/leads (known condition)
2) **Test** the circuit
3) **Re-prove** the tester/function/leads
4) **Record** the value + judgement (Pass / Suspicious / Stop-and-check)

Typical dead tests for this exercise (training rig context):
- **CPC continuity** (low-ohms) to confirm the protective path is present and continuous.
- **Insulation Resistance (IR)** between conductors to confirm no leakage paths.
- **Polarity logic (dead method)** to confirm the switch is in the line conductor and the correct terminals are used.

Important: the student does not energise the rig. Testing is to confirm the circuit is safe and ready for results recording and the next supervised stage.

content.title: Check Your Understanding: Terminal Groups + Tests

questions.questionText: Which terminal group in the ceiling rose connects the permanent live from the CU to the switch feed?
questions.hint: It is the permanent live group.

questions.questionText: What colour sleeving must be applied to a blue core that is used as a switch return (switched live)?
questions.hint: It must be identified as a live conductor.

questions.questionText: Which test checks there is no unwanted leakage path between Line and Neutral conductors?
questions.hint: This test uses a DC test voltage and reads in MΩ.

questions.questionText: How does the Switched Live terminal group differ from the Loop group when the switch is OFF?
questions.expectedAnswer: The loop stays permanently live, but the switched live is not live when the switch is off
questions.hint: One is permanent; one depends on switch position.

content.title: Worked Example: Recording Dead Test Results (Example Fields)
content.given: A student has completed a 1-way lighting circuit on a training rig and performed CPC continuity and IR tests. (Instrument fields shown as examples.)

steps.description: Record the instrument used (and serial number if your results sheet requires it).
steps.result: Instrument: MFT (example), Serial No.: optional / per sheet

steps.description: Record CPC continuity reading (low-ohms range, leads nulled if required).
Record IR reading at the rig-specified test voltage (e.g., 500 V DC if that is the procedure for the exercise).
steps.result: IR (L–N, L–CPC, N–CPC as required): >999 MΩ (example over-range)

steps.description: Apply the routine: re-prove and then make a judgement (Pass / Suspicious / Stop-and-check).

content.notes: Example values are for learning. Your rig/exercise sheet may specify the exact test voltage and what to record at each point.

questions.questionText: In a 3-plate rose, which two conductors share the Neutral terminal block?
questions.hint: Neutral is not switched; it joins at the rose.

questions.questionText: What IR test voltage does your rig procedure specify for this exercise (for example 250 V DC or 500 V DC)?
questions.hint: Use the exercise sheet / rig procedure (don’t guess).

questions.questionText: True or False: CPC sleeving is only required if the backbox is metal.
questions.hint: Identification is required at terminations so function is clear.

questions.questionText: You get an unexpected test result that does not match your circuit map. What is your safest next action before concluding the circuit is wrong?
expectedAnswer: Re-prove the tester and check setup, then re-test
Check leads/ports/function and re-prove, then re-test
questions.hint: Remove the tester/leads/settings as the hidden cause first.

questions.questionText: Explain why a dead inspection must happen before any meter testing, and how Prove → Test → Re-prove protects you from recording a false result.
questions.expectedAnswer: Inspection finds stop-and-fix issues (exposed copper, loose terminations, missing CPC) that make testing unsafe or meaningless. Prove → Test → Re-prove confirms the tester and leads are working before and after, so an odd reading is less likely to be caused by failed leads, wrong ports, or incorrect settings.
